subject: statistics
title: Type I and Type II Errors

problem.statementHtml: Consider a statistical test with a significance level of α = 0.05. What is the probability that we reject the null hypothesis when it is actually true?
hints: Think about the definition of type I error.
Recall the concept of power in hypothesis testing.
Consider the relationship between α and β.
problem.solutionHtml:
To solve this, we need to understand the difference between type I and type II errors. A type I error occurs when we reject a true null hypothesis, whereas a type II error occurs when we fail to reject a false null hypothesis.

Given α = 0.05, the probability of a type I error is α itself. This means that there is a 5% chance of rejecting the null hypothesis when it is actually true.

commonMistakes: Confusing type I and type II errors

problem.statementHtml: Consider a statistical test with significance level α = 0.05. Suppose we reject the null hypothesis when it is actually true. What kind of error have we committed? Explain why.
hints: Think about what happens when you set up a false positive scenario
Recall that α represents the maximum probability of Type I errors
Consider the consequences of rejecting a true null hypothesis
problem.solutionHtml:
We have committed a Type I error. This is because we rejected the null hypothesis when it was actually true, which means we incorrectly concluded that there is an effect when none exists.

This type of error occurs when the significance level α is too low. In this case, the probability of rejecting the null hypothesis when it's true (Type I error) exceeds α.

statementHtml: Consider a statistical test with significance level α = 0.05. What is the probability of making a Type I error?
hints: Think about the definition of a Type I error.
Recall that α represents the maximum acceptable probability of rejecting a true null hypothesis.
Use the formula for the probability of a Type I error.
solutionHtml:
To find the probability of making a Type I error, we need to recall the definition:

\(\mathbf{P(Type\ I\ Error) = P(Reject\ H_0 | H_0\ true)}.\)

Since α represents the maximum acceptable probability of rejecting a true null hypothesis, we can set up an inequality:

\(\mathbf{P(Type\ I\ Error) ≤ α}.\)

Solving for P(Type I Error), we get:

\(\mathbf{P(Type\ I\ Error) = α}.\)

This means that the probability of making a Type I error is equal to the significance level.
